items.title: Mbappe wants Â£230m from former club PSG
items.summary: France captain Kylian Mbappe is seeking Â£231.5m from Paris St-Germain, with his former club demanding Â£211m, as their long-running dispute reaches the Paris courts.

items.title: Mars orbiter narrows down the exact path of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS by 'ten-fold,' surprising scientists
items.summary: Scientists from the European Space Agency have significantly narrowed down the trajectory of the interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS thanks to data from the alien comet's recent flyby of Mars, allowing for more accurate future observations.

items.summary: Scientists say a new kind of AI could bridge the gap between current systems and machines that learn and think more like us.

items.title: The TV hit that sparked the Korean drama boom
items.summary: Family drama Reply 1988 paved the way for other Korean hits like Squid Game

items.title: Parts of Arizona are being sucked dry, with areas of land sinking 6 inches per year, satellite data reveals
items.summary: Groundwater extraction has caused parts of the Willcox Basin to subside by up to 12 feet since the 1950s. New research reveals that some areas sunk by 3 feet in just 4 years.

items.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
items.summary: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

items.title: 240 million-year-old 'warrior' crocodile ancestor from Pangaea had plated armor â€” and it looked just like a dinosaur
items.summary: The armor-plated lizard is an ancestor of modern crocodiles and lived just before dinosaurs took over Earth.

items.title: Underwater volcano off Oregon coast likely won't erupt until mid-to-late 2026
items.summary: Researchers thought that Axial Seamount might erupt in 2025, but recent data suggest the underwater volcano could take a bit longer to blow its top.

items.title: Scientists detect monster blast from nearby star powerful enough to rip the atmosphere off a planet
items.summary: In a small blow to the search for extraterrestrial life, a nearby star shot out a strong enough coronal mass ejection to strip away the atmosphere of any rocky planets that could have been in the way.

items.title: 'Stranded' astronauts aboard Chinese space station are preparing to come home â€” but no date has been announced
items.summary: Three astronauts remain stuck on China's Tiangong space station after errant debris struck their return capsule last week. But their return vessel has already arrived, meaning a flight home will come sooner rather than later.

items.title: Blue Origin New Glenn rocket: New launch window for historic Mars mission after solar storm delay
items.summary: Twin Mars spacecraft were due to launch on Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket on Nov. 12, but an active sun prompted NASA to delay its mission until Thursday (Nov. 13).

items.title: Brain benefits of exercise come from the bloodstream â€” and they may be transferrable, mouse study finds
items.summary: Exercise strengthens both the body and the mind, and researchers are uncovering the molecular messengers that make the connection. The messengers can also be transferred from an active mouse to a sedentary one.

items.summary: A previously unknown Indigenous population lived in central Argentina for nearly 8,500 years, a new genetic study finds.

items.title: New antivenom works against 17 dangerous African snake species, study suggests
items.summary: Scientists have developed a nanobody-based antivenom that neutralizes toxins from most African cobras, mambas and the rinkhals, which could offer safer, scalable protection beyond existing snakebite treatments.

items.summary: Experiments show that a time crystal based on magnons can interact with mechanical waves without being destroyed.

items.title: James Webb telescope may have found the first stars in the universe, new study claims
items.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope may have discovered Population III stars, the universe's first generation of stars. They may tell us more about how galaxies form.

items.title: Is a 1768 painting the real birth of modern art?
items.summary: Why An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump was way ahead of its time

items.title: Diagnostic dilemma: A woman's homemade juice led to life-threatening 'toxic squash syndrome'
items.summary: In the first reported case of its kind in Canada, a woman fell violently ill after consuming the juice of a bitter gourd.

items.title: Tiny spiders that build giant 'puppet' decoys from disembodied prey discovered in Peru and Philippines
items.summary: Researchers have documented the strange antics of two tropical spider species that build giant, arachnid-shaped decoys out of silk, plant matter and prey remains in their webs.

items.title: 'I deeply hurt people by moving to Saudi Arabia'
items.summary: In an interview with BBC Sport, Ashleigh Plumptre says she regrets losing the trust of some LGBT fans in women's football by moving to Saudi Arabia.

items.title: Humble & sweet, but a lion - the story of the first female Â£1m player
items.summary: Meet the person behind women's football's first Â£1m player, Arsenal's new superstar forward Olivia Smith.

items.title: 'People looked at me like I was a something, not someone'
items.summary: In a candid interview, World Cup winner Heather Fisher discusses losing her hair and the struggle she had with her identity.

items.title: 'He fixes what needs fixing' - why Raducanu turned to Nadal's ex-coach
items.summary: Emma Raducanu recently appointed another full-time coach in Spaniard Francisco Roig - BBC Sport speaks to those who know him best.

items.title: 'He has made young players dream' - the making of Liverpool icon Salah
items.summary: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.
